source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: In Sakha, too, 3SG possessive marking is used to signal situational identifiability on nouns referring to natural phenomena.
sah: ҥургуhуна ол да буоллар эрдэ тахсар.
en: nevertheless, the snowdrops come out early [snowdrop–POSS.3SG that PTL AUX–COND early go.out–PRSPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: In Sakha, too, 3SG possessive marking is used to signal situational identifiability on nouns referring to natural phenomena.

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: However, in Sakha it is not only the 3SG possessive suffix that is used in ‘non-possessive’ functions, but other possessive suffixes as well, most especially the 2SG possessive suffix (88a-c), but also the 1SG possessive suffix (88d). These function mainly to establish anaphoric reference and to indicate that the entity in question will continue as the topic of discourse (88b, c), but they can also be used to mark contrastive focus (e.g. 88a) or just for emotional purposes, as shown here by the 1SG possessive marker (88d). In addition, they add a nuance of involving the addressee in what is being said. This is in stark contrast to other Turkic languages (with the exception of Dolgan, see below): in the corpus analysed by Fraurud, out of 3,492 nouns none carried second person possessive suffixes (Fraurud 2001: 251).
sah: Оттон сылгыҥ буоллаҕына бэйэтэ хаһан аһыыр буолан…
en: But horses, however, since they eat by themselves by digging (for grass under the snow)… [CP horse–POSS.2SG however self–POSS.3SG dig–PF.CVB food–VR–PRSPT AUX–PF.CVB]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha

notes: However, in Sakha it is not only the 3SG possessive suffix that is used in ‘non-possessive’ functions, but other possessive suffixes as well, most especially the 2SG possessive suffix (88a-c), but also the 1SG possessive suffix (88d). These function mainly to establish anaphoric reference and to indicate that the entity in question will continue as the topic of discourse (88b, c), but they can also be used to mark contrastive focus (e.g. 88a) or just for emotional purposes, as shown here by the 1SG possessive marker (88d). This is in stark contrast to other Turkic languages (with the exception of Dolgan, see below): in the corpus analysed by Fraurud, out of 3,492 nouns none carried second person possessive suffixes (Fraurud 2001: 251).
sah: Сити соҕотох гилабаҥ барытын бас биллэ.
en: Just this headman alone took everything into his possession. [EMPH–this single headman–POSS.2SG all–ACC.3SG take.into.possession–PST.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: However, in Sakha it is not only the 3SG possessive suffix that is used in ‘non-possessive’ functions, but other possessive suffixes as well, most especially the 2SG possessive suffix (88a-c), but also the 1SG possessive suffix (88d). This is in stark contrast to other Turkic languages (with the exception of Dolgan, see below): in the corpus analysed by Fraurud, out of 3,492 nouns none carried second person possessive suffixes (Fraurud 2001: 251).
en: Those healers are clairvoyants (lit. know how to see clearly), it seems. [that medicine–AGNR–PL–POSS.2SG see.clearly–IPF.CVB know–PRSPT–PL AUX–PSTPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: However, in Sakha it is not only the 3SG possessive suffix that is used in ‘non-possessive’ functions, but other possessive suffixes as well, most especially the 2SG possessive suffix (88a-c), but also the 1SG possessive suffix (88d). These function mainly to establish anaphoric reference and to indicate that the entity in question will continue as the topic of discourse (88b, c), but they can also be used to mark contrastive focus (e.g. 88a) or just for emotional purposes, as shown here by the 1SG possessive marker (88d). In addition, they add a nuance of involving the addressee in what is being said. This is in stark contrast to other Turkic languages (with the exception of Dolgan, see below): in the corpus analysed by Fraurud, out of 3,492 nouns none carried second person possessive suffixes (Fraurud 2001: 251).
sah: Ол өлө сыһан баран били хотонум маһыгар…
en: After having nearly died (I worked) in the cattle-shed’s wood… [that die–IPF.CVB IRR–PF.CVB SEQ–PF.CVB that.one cattle.shed–POSS.1SG wood–DAT.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: Here, the function of marking the relation between a highly salient participant in the discourse and an entity that plays an important role, but is not actually possessed, is performed by the normal possessive suffixes which agree in person and number with the main discourse participant.
sah: Бэҕэһэ мин ойуурга сырыттым арай туох эрэ сып-сымнаҕаһы үктээтим көрбүтүм кутуйах эбит куттанаммын охтон түстүм кутуйаҕым куотан хаалла.
en: Yesterday I was walking through the woods. Suddenly I stepped onto something very soft. I looked and saw it was a mouse. I got a fright and fell down. The mouse (lit. my mouse) ran away. [yesterday 1SG woods–DAT walk–PST–POSS.1SG suddenly what PTL INTS~soft–ACC step.on–PST–POSS.1SG see–PSTPT–POSS.1SG mouse AUX–PSTPT be.afraid–PF.CVB–PRED.1SG fall–PF.CVB descend–PST–POSS.1SG mouse–POSS.1SG flee–PF.CVB RES–PST.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: Example (96) comes from a narrative about a group of bandits (the ‘possessors’) who are tricked by an old man (the ‘possessum’) into following him into a trap.
sah: Ииҥэ диээччи киһилэрэ сырга көлүммүттэрин кэннэ ол оҕонҥордоро мииннэринэн кэлбит.
en: Saying this the old man, after they harnessed their sled, the old man came riding. [thus say–HAB man–POSS.3PL sled harness–REFL–PSTPT–ACC.3PL back.part–POSS.3SG that old.man–POSS.3PL ride–CAUS–REFL–PF.CVB come–PSTPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: Furthermore, in Udihe use of the possessive suffixes in conjunction with the Alienable Possession suffix with proper names (97a) and nouns referring to humans (97b) presupposes that the person concerned is well known to both the speaker and the listener. Thus, the ‘Sergey’ referred to in (97a) “may be a relative or friend of the interlocutor”, while the ‘girl’ in (97b) was the linguist come to work with her consultant; the sentence was said by the consultant’s husband (N/T: 139). In Sakha, this function appears to be fulfilled by second person singular possessive marking (98a-c)
sah: Бүтэрэн били түөттү сыл ааһар били Поповаҥ оскуолатыттан ити бардылар.
en: They finished that Popova's school, where you pass four years (of curriculum) in one, they left from there. [end–CAUS–PF.CVB that.one four–DIST year pass–PRSPT that.one P.–POSS.2SG school–ABL.3SG this go–PST–PL]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: Furthermore, in Udihe use of the possessive suffixes in conjunction with the Alienable Possession suffix with proper names (97a) and nouns referring to humans (97b) presupposes that the person concerned is well known to both the speaker and the listener. Thus, the ‘Sergey’ referred to in (97a) “may be a relative or friend of the interlocutor”, while the ‘girl’ in (97b) was the linguist come to work with her consultant; the sentence was said by the consultant’s husband (N/T: 139). In Sakha, this function appears to be fulfilled by second person singular possessive marking (98a-c)
sah: Күүстээх Бөчүөхөбүҥ отто ол салаакка баран баран ол суох буолбута бүтэн.
en: Küste:x BöTüöxov (i.e. strong BöTüöxov) died (lit. became non-existent) after going to the soldiers. [strength–PROP B.–POSS.2SG CP that soldier–DAT go–PF.CVB SEQ–PF.CVB that non.existence become–PSTPT–POSS.3SG end–PF.CVB]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.1 The ‘non-possessive’ use of possessive suffixes in Sakha
notes: Furthermore, in Udihe use of the possessive suffixes in conjunction with the Alienable Possession suffix with proper names (97a) and nouns referring to humans (97b) presupposes that the person concerned is well known to both the speaker and the listener. Thus, the ‘Sergey’ referred to in (97a) “may be a relative or friend of the interlocutor”, while the ‘girl’ in (97b) was the linguist come to work with her consultant; the sentence was said by the consultant’s husband (N/T: 139). In Sakha, this function appears to be fulfilled by second person singular possessive marking (98a-c)
en: Look, she understands Sakha, it seems. [PTL hear–PRSPT AUX–PSTPT this–POSS.2SG Sakha–ADVR]
